prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: To maximize continuum sensitivity in band 7, we will average the signal over the maximum 2x3.75 GHz bandwidth of the 2SB receivers. Since these are continuum observations with the 12-m array only, the 64-input correlator will be used in the Time Divison Mode, which provides a wide bandwidth and a coarse spectral resolution.

The most compact configuration of the 12-m array has a resolution of 1", but it is scheduled during the antiplantic winter (December - February), limiting the chance of band-7 observations. Therefore, we request the less compact configuration, C36-2, which has a synthesized beam of 0.5" and a night time LST range of 04-20 hr.

Our sources have a typical flux densities 20 mJy at 500 um. Extrapolating to 870 um based on a modified blackbody SED, the 870um flux density is ~4 mJy. Given the typical source diameter of 1.5" for SMGs, each source can be resolved into ~9 beams. We thus request a sensitivity of 0.11 mJy/beam to achieve a SNR of 4 per beam and a total SNR of 12, which allows accurate measurements of the centroid position.

Therefore, we request the less compact configuration, C36-2, which has a synthesized beam of 0.5" and a night time LST range of 04-20 hr.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Submillimeter Galaxies (SMGs) are the most likely progenitors of modern massive elliptical galaxies. Their clustering strength indicates that they inhabit massive (~1e13 Msun) halos at z ~ 2.5. Current theories predict that the majority of gas accreted by such halos should be shock-heated to temperatures ~ 10 million K. Furthermore, one predicts that this hot plasma cools too slow to sustain the extreme star formation rates of SMGs. So how do the SMGs acquire their massive reservoirs of cold gas and will their current starbursts lead to rapid quenching? To resolve these outstanding questions, we have started a program to use QSO absorption line spectroscopy to probe the circum-galactic medium of SMGs. The proposed ALMA band-7 snapshots is critical to this program. We aim at determining sub-arcsecond positions of a sample of 30 SMGs that lie within 30 arcsec of a high-redshift QSO sightline to allow future spectroscopy. This is currently impossible because the position uncertainties of the SMGs from far-IR imaging is ~5 arcsec in radius.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
